snippet: Google has purchased a small company, called Sparrow, that made Gmail on iPhones a delight. Now, the chief executive says, his company will work on "a bigger vision" using its knowledge of the iPhone. What else could Google build inside of e-mail?
abstract: Google has purchased a small company, called Sparrow, that made Gmail on iPhones a delight. Now, the chief executive says, his company will work on "a bigger vision" using its knowledge of the iPhone. What else could Google build inside of e-mail?

headline.main: Google to Apple: We've Got Mail!

byline.original: By QUENTIN HARDY and CLAIRE CAIN MILLER

snippet: Google announced significant improvements to maps in 11 countries, using an in-house project called "Ground Truth." Google says it believes that geographic data is much more accurate if it comes from one source. What it means is that Microsoft, Am...
abstract: Google announced significant improvements to maps in 11 countries, using an in-house project called "Ground Truth." Google says it believes that geographic data is much more accurate if it comes from one source. What it means is that Microsoft, Amazon and Apple better be prepared to spend a fortune to even approach Google.

snippet: A research report suggests more bad news for Research in Motion. The cellphone carriers could use Windows 8, not BlackBerry, to counterbalance the power of Android and Apple.
abstract: A research report suggests more bad news for Research in Motion. The cellphone carriers could use Windows 8, not BlackBerry, to counterbalance the power of Android and Apple.

headline.main: Will Windows Phones Replace BlackBerrys as Bargaining Chip?

snippet: With the right software, adding music to a smartphone video clip can be done easily on a phone, tablet or computer.
abstract: With the right software, adding music to a smartphone video clip can be done easily on a phone, tablet or computer.

snippet: What is your favorite misheard song lyric?
abstract: What is your favorite misheard song lyric?

headline.main: Canceled Berets, Cross-Eyed Bears and Other Enduring Mondegreens

snippet: The ruling by a British judge is the latest twist in a global legal battle over patents between bitter rivals in the smartphone and tablet businesses.
abstract: Eric Pfanner Advertising column observes a British judge has ordered Apple to post notices on its Web site and to take out newspaper ads declaring that Samsung did not infringe Apple design patents; points out the ruling is the latest twist in a global legal battle over patents between bitter rivals in the smartphone and tablet businesses.

headline.main: Judge Tells Apple to Advertise a Win for Samsung
headline.print_headline: Judge Tells Apple to Advertise a Win for Samsung

snippet: An accounting charge related to Microsoft’s acquisition of an online advertising business led to a rare quarterly loss for the software giant. Revenue from Windows declined.
abstract: Accounting charge related to Microsoft’s acquisition of an online advertising business leads to a rare quarterly loss; fiscal fourth-quarter loss was $492 million, or 6 cents a share, compared with profit of $5.87 billion, or 69 cents a share, in the year-ago quarter; revenue was $18.06 billion, up from $17.37 billion.

headline.main: Microsoft Reports Loss After a Write-Down
headline.print_headline: Microsoft Reports Loss After a Write-Down

snippet: The search giant reported an increase in revenue and profit in the second quarter, though ad revenue per click declined and Motorola Mobility lost money.
abstract: Google reports second-quarter profit of $2.79 billion, or $8.42 a share, from $2.51 billion, or $7.68 a share, in the year-ago quarter; revenue was $12.21 billion, up 35 percent from $9.03 billion.

headline.main: As Google Changes, Its Revenue Keeps Rising
headline.print_headline: As Google Changes, Its Revenue Keeps Rising

snippet: The 13 percent gain in quarterly net income was in line with Wall Street expectations.
abstract: Verizon Communications reports second-quarter profit of $1.8 billion, or 64 cents a share, up 13.4 percent from the year-ago quarter; revenue rose 3.7 percent to $28.6 billion; company says smartphone sales and revenue from its cellphone subscribers helped its results.

headline.main: Verizon’s Profit Rises as Subscribers Grow More Slowly
headline.print_headline: Verizon’s Profit Rises as Subscribers Grow More Slowly

snippet: Nokia said its loss in the second quarter more than tripled, but shares rose as much as 10 percent after the company said it had sold four million Lumia smartphones running Windows.
abstract: Nokia reports second-quarter loss of 1.4 billion euros ($1.7 billion); revenue fell 19 percent to 7.54 billion euros from the year-ago quarter; company posted the first tangible gains in its turbulent transition to a Windows-based smartphone business.

headline.main: Despite a Loss, Nokia Reports a Windows-Based Lift
headline.print_headline: Nokia Loss Tripled in 2nd Quarter, but Smartphone Sales Increased
